titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1 V:30. Tuesday. I received a Letter from S. A Turner of Scituate, with a Petition signed by 750 names of that neighbourhood, praying for a Canal at the mouth of Taunton-river— At the meeting of the House, I asked unanimous permission to present it— Lewis Williams moved to suspend the rules, for the reception of Memorials and Petitions intercepted by the sparring debates of yesterday—upon this the vote was only 24 to 15. No Quorum— Members coming in I renewed my request for unanimous consent which was refused—vote taken again No Quorum. Call of the House demanded by Lytle of Ohio, and refused— Call of the House again demanded by George Grennell, who asks for the yeas and nays. Carried. 101 to 18: Making with the Speaker by his construction a Quorum— My name was called, and then the call was superseded, members constantly coming in— I asked again unanimous consent to present my Petition from Scituate. No—said one voice. I moved that the rule should be suspended— Carried 96 to 47—just rubbed through— My Petition was received, and without reading referred to the Committee on Roads and Canals.— Lewis Williams then moved the suspension of the Rules, for the reception of Petitions and Memorials from the States, and calls for the yeas and nays—rejected 82 to 84. Parker of New-Jersey asks to introduce a Resolution and fails— Archer from the Committee of foreign Affairs made a report recommending the purchase of Washington’s papers, and proposing to provide for the payment by an amendment to the General Appropriation-Bill. Jarvis from the Committee on the Public Buildings reported an amendatory Appropriation Bill— The Speaker took up the commutation pension Bill, and Thomas M. Marshall resumed his argument commenced on the 6th of last Month, and spoke till 1. O’Clock without finishing— Then the Speaker read a Message from the President, with a Report from the Secretary of State on the counterfeiting of foreign Coins—referred to the Committee on the judiciary— Lastly came the special order of the day— Wilde’s Amendment to the first Resolution reported by the Committee of Ways and Means.— Benjamin Hardin of Kentucky spoke three hours— After which Chilton moved to adjourn—rejected by yeas and nays 68 to 82— Ten minutes after, another motion to adjourn rejected 76 to 84— After another 10 minutes third motion to adjourn, carried 82 to 80— Spent the Evening at whist.
2. V:30. Wednesday.

James Blair a member of the House of Representatives from South-Carolina shot himself last Evening at his lodgings at Dowson’s N. 1. after reading part of an affectionate Letter from his wife to Governor Murphy of Alabama, who was alone in the chamber with him, and a fellow lodger with him at the same house—

At the Meeting of the House, George M’Duffie, announced the decease of Mr Blair: alluding to the Catastrophe of the death of Thomas T Bouldin, and said that the decease of Mr Blair had been equally sudden— He expressed his disapprobation of the practice of pronouncing panegyrics upon members who have ceased to live, and are beyond the reach alike of censure and of praise— That panegyrics were useless to those to whom the person was known, and uninteresting to those who knew him not— He moved that the usual Resolutions on similar occasions should be adopted— That the members of the House would attend the funeral at 4 O’Clock this afternoon— That they would testify their respect for the memory of James Blair, by wearing crape thirty days— That a Message be sent to the Senate, announcing the Event; and that a Committee of
Arrangements be appointed to superintend the funeral— The house then adjourned— Poor Blair— The indifference and insincerity of M’Duffie’s remarks were as unfeeling as if his heart had been of marble— There is a gloomy churlishness in the character of M’Duffie averse enough to Panegyric, but if Blair had been of his own political party, he would have lauded him to the skies— Blair was a man of amiable natural disposition, of excellent feelings, of sterling good sense, and of brilliant parts, irredeemably ruined by the single vice of intemperance, which had crept upon him insensibly to himself, till it had bloated his body to a mountain—prostrated his intellect, and vitiated his temper to madness— He had paid three hundred dollars fine, for beating and breaking the bones of Duff Green, because he had charged the Union party of South-Carolina, with being Tories.— He had discharged a pistol, at an actress on the Theatre at Washington, from one of the boxes— He had within the last ten days given the lie to Henry L Pinckney while speaking in his place in the House of Representatives, and he was in the constant habit of bringing a loaded pistol with him to the House— The chances were quite equal that he should have shot almost any other man than himself. Yet he was one of the most kind hearted men in the world; a tender and affectionate husband and father, and has left a wife devoted to him, and children to whom his death is perhaps a blessing— It was no doubt a difficult task for M’Duffie to announce his decease to the House in an appropriate manner— But the expedient of evading all note of sympathy with the feelings of his friends, by an affected and hollow pretence of dislike to all obituary panegyric was not felicitous— Half an hour after the adjournment of the House I went into the Senate chamber just as Mr Preston of South-Carolina was moving their adjournment— I went home, and at four P.M—returned to the Capitol— The funeral Service was performed by the two chaplains of the two houses.— The Episcopal service was not read— It is by the principles of that Church interdicted in cases of suicide— I went to the Cemetery, near the Navy-Yard, in a Carriage with Jeremiah M’Lene of Ohio, and two other members of the House— There was a short prayer made by Mr Hatch at the common vault— I returned in the Hack, with my associates to the Capitol, and thence home in my barouche— Evening visit from judge Nathaniel Pope of Illinois, with Mr Lacy of Nashville, appointed a judge in Arkansas—
3. V:30. Thursday.

Morning visit from Hiland Hall of Vermont, with a Mr Hastings of Albany, New-York one of the Delegation from the Memorialists of that place— Mr Hastings told me, that he was at the President’s last Saturday with Job Pierson of the State of New-York and that the President asked him when the House would take the Question upon the Deposites; Pierson told him in the course of this week— The President said to him, the sooner the better— That Congress had been talking four Months on the Subject, and making Panic Speeches— That talking longer upon it would only work further mischief, and that if the House would decide the question, in one week after, nothing more would be heard of suffering and distress— Hall told me that the Administration party, intended to put the previous Question on the Resolutions reported by the Committee of Ways and Means this day— At the House Edward T. White of Louisiana moved to suspend the rules, to call the States for Memorials and Petitions, beginning at the South— This motion was rejected. Elisha Whittlesey from the Committee of Claims reported a Bill for the payment of
claims for property lost, captured or destroyed by the Enemy, while in the Military service of the United States, during the late War with Great-Britain, and the Indian Wars subsequent thereto, and for other purposes— Read twice, by the title, and referred to a Committee of the whole House, and made the special order of the day for the 11th. instt. Edward Everett from the Committee of foreign Affairs reported a Bill making compensation for certain diplomatic services, and for other purposes: read twice and referred to the Committee of the whole House on the State of the Union— Mardis’s Resolution was taken up— Chilton Allan, finished his Speech, and Thomas Corwin of Ohio took the floor for to-morrow— A Message was received from the President, but not read— It enclosed a Communication from the Governor of New-York—and a copy of one from the Governor of New-Jersey, requesting the consent of Congress to an agreement between the two States, for the settlement of their disputed boundary line. The commutation pension bill followed— Thomas A. Marshall concluded and William Baylies of Massachusetts took the floor for to-morrow— At one, the standing order of the day, the Resolutions of the Committee of Ways and Means, and Wilde’s Amendment, was taken up— Hardin spoke an hour and a half and finished— George M’Duffie succeeded, and after speaking about an hour, gave way to a motion of adjournment, made by William S. Archer: which was carried by yeas and nays 118 to 84.— Aaron Ward of New-York told me they allowed this day to pass without taking the previous Question, on account of the unexpected loss of yesterday.— I had an evening visit from Mr John Connell of Philadelphia, with his Son— Mrs Adams was very unwell— Confined to her chamber.

4. V:15. Friday.— At the House, Connor of North-Carolina, from a select Committee reported a Bill to establish assay Offices of the United States Mints, in the gold Districts of North-Carolina, South-Carolina, Georgia and Virginia— Read twice and referred to a Committee of the whole House and made the order of the day for to-morrow. The Message received yesterday from the President was read and referred to the Committee on the Judiciary— The Speaker laid before the House a Letter from the Secretary of the Treasury, and one from the Postmaster General— Then the first hour from 11 to 12. was occupied by Mr Corwin, of Ohio, upon Mardis’s deposite Resolution, without finishing— Then from 12 to 1. William Baylies, and after him John Cramer of New-York, discoursed upon the Pension commutation Bill; but a Motion was made by George R. Gilmer that the Bill be recommitted to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— Pending this motion, one O’Clock came, and with it the special order of the day. M’Duffie resumed the floor, on Mr Wilde’s Amendment to the Resolutions on the Bank and deposite questions reported by the Committee of Ways and Means.— he spoke till near four O’Clock— At the moment when he ceased, of which he had given me a previous signal, I addressed the Speaker, with a very loud voice— So did also two or three other members, one of whom was John G. Watmough, whose purpose only was to obtain the floor to resign it to me— The Speaker however gave the floor to John Y. Mason of Virginia, who after a short Speech, moved the previous Question, concerted before-hand out of the house, and which the whole house knew was to be moved and carried this day— There was a small majority of the House, to second the previous question— Vance of Ohio moved to adjourn—lost by yeas and nays 103 to 119. Chilton of Kentucky moved that the first Resolution reported by the Committee of Ways and Means should be laid on the table— That the Bank of the United States ought not to be rechartered—rejected by yeas and nays. 82 to 136— Burd moved that the 2d. 3d. and 4th. reported Resolutions lie on the table. Barringer called for a division of the question, first upon the 2d. and 3d. and then on the 4th. On the second and third the motion was rejected 95 to 125. and Burd withdrew his
motion with regard to the 4th. Resolution— The previous Question was then put and carried, by yeas and nays 114 to 106— The Speaker decided that by the Lex Parliamentaria, the Main Question cut off all proposed amendments, and was upon all four of the Resolutions reported by the Committee of Ways and Means, although a separate Question might be taken upon each of the Resolutions— Mr Wilde intreated of the courtesy of the House to take the Question upon his amendment—rejected— The question was taken by yeas and nays upon each of the Resolutions separately—the first—that the Bank of the U.S. ought not to be rechartered was carried 134 to 82. All the South-Carolina members except M’Duffie, and all the Georgia members except Wilde voting for it— The second Resolution, that the public deposites ought not to be restored to the Bank of the United States, passed by a vote of 118 to 103.— Burges lost his vote, being doubtful whether he was within the bar, when his name was called— He asked to vote, and I moved a suspension of the rule, to allow him to vote—but there were not two thirds so indulgent, and he lost his vote— The third Resolution, that the State Banks should be continued as depositories, and that Congress should further regulate the subject by Law, passed 117 to 105— The fourth Resolution, directing the appointment of a Select Committee for a Bank investigation, with power to visit the Bank and any of its branches, was adopted by 175 to 42—the most exceptionable of all the Resolutions by the largest vote— The Committee appointed were Thomas of Maryland, Edward Everett, Muhlenberg of Pennsylvania, Mason of Virginia, Ellsworth of Connecticut, Abijah Mann of New-York, and Robert T. Lytle of Ohio— Thomas of Louisiana moved that the House should adjourn over to Monday, which was carried— Wilde made another effort, that the rule be suspended to enable him to offer again his Resolution, that the reasons assigned by the Secretary for removing the deposites are insufficient and unsatisfactory—but Polk moved the house to adjourn, and the vote was carried— The Speaker declared the House adjourned— But upon an objection made he proceeded as if the House was yet in Session— I asked him if the House was adjourned or not— He said he had been about to adjourn, but did not declare the House adjourned— I insisted that I had heard him declare the House adjourned.— He said he had been eight hours in the Chair, was very unwell, and scarcely knew what he had done— This entirely disarmed me— The vote for adjournment was 124 to 73— About 8 O’Clock P.M— It was near 9 when I got home, utterly exhausted, and equally dispirited and desponding— The thought that an American house of Representatives should pass such a Resolution as the fourth, reported by the Committee of Ways and Means, mortifies me beyond expression— There was nothing more arbitrary or tyrannical in the domiciliary visits of Revolutionary France. It proves how feeble even in this Country are all the principles of Freedom, in collision with a current of popular prejudice or passion.
5. VI. Saturday.

I returned the visit of Aaron Vanderpoel of Kinderhook— He comes from the native Village of Vice President van Buren, and is one of the Champions of the present administration in the house— His wife is a Sister of Charles Foot who was formerly a member of the House who was friendly to me— Vanderpoel himself is somewhat studious of civility to me, though we are at the opposite Poles upon almost every question that is taken in the house— I went afterwards
to the Office of the National Intelligencer, and enquired of Mr Gales, when he would publish the Speech I had intended to make yesterday, and which was cut off by the Previous Question— He said, if I could let him have it next Monday, it should be published in the paper of Thursday.— While I was with him, Mr Clay and Mr Preston of South-Carolina came in together, upon which I retired, and all the remnant of the day, and Evening was absorbed in arranging the fragments of Manuscript, of my Speech, and in preparing the extracts of the citations which I was to adduce— Received visits from Governor Lincoln, and from Elisha Whittlesey of Ohio, one of the worthiest, most intelligent, and most laborious members of the House—Chairman of the Committee of Claims, and a most consciencious and indefatigable performer of his duty— With him were two persons named Averill, who came to see me to gratify their curiosity.

6. VI. Sunday— Stormy day.— I attended at St. John’s Church, and heard Mr Hawley read the morning Service, for the first Sunday after Easter, and discourse from 1. Corinthians 6.20. “For ye are bought with a price: therefore glorify God in your body, and in your Spirit, which are God’s.” The doctrine of this chapter is that the Christian is not his own property, but belongs Soul and body to God—whence the Apostle draws an exhortation to moral practice. This illustration is an appeal to the reverence of the Corinthians for the sacred rights of property. But it is a figurative illustration— Property is of human institution and arises from the relations of men, with one another. There can be no relation of Property between Man and God— The Apostle therefore accommodates his discourse to the poverty of human language, and to the narrowness of human conceptions, and urges the abstinence from crime, under the sense of obligation to preserve the property of God— He rebukes them sharply too forgoing to Law with one another, before the unjust—or unbelievers, and asks why they do not sooner suffer themselves to be defrauded? This chapter has been the occasion of great usurpations by the ecclesiastical establishments of the Roman Catholic Church, and it is one of the numerous exemplifications of the gross perversion of the language of Scripture to the purposes of priestly avarice and ambition.— Mr Hawley gave notice that owing to the inclemency of the weather there would be no evening service— I went after dinner to the Presbyterian Church but found that also closed— The remainder of the day, I was still engaged in arranging and completing my Manuscript, with the aid of my wife, of my Son John, and of his wife.

7. VI. Monday.— I finished the preparation of my manuscript so far as to send by my Son John to the National Intelligencer Office, about half of my intended Speech, with the extracts— Weather yet stormy.— At the House, it being the weekly day for receiving Memorials and Petitions, I found Dutee J. Pearce of Rhode-Island presenting Petitions from that State against the Bank of the United States, and against the restoration of the Deposites.— The call for the States was carried from Rhode-Island Southward through the Union—States and Territories—one hundred and forty eight Memorials Petitions, and authenticated Proceedings of public Meetings were presented.— Nearly one half of them being for or against the recharter of the Bank of the United States, and for or against the removal of the Deposites— In presenting these many of the members introduced them with short Speeches, and not unfrequently the Speech was against the purport of the Petition which it introduced. This is a singularity confined entirely to the Memorials and Petitions relating to the Bank of the United States—a subject of great party excitement and controversy.— The other subjects upon which the memorials are most numerous, are for Post-Offices and Post-roads, and Petitions for Pensions for Services during the Revolutionary War and since— Uriah Tracy
thirty-years ago, used to say that the Soldiers of the Revolution claimants never died—that they were immortal. Had he lived to this time he would have seen that they multiply with the lapse of time— As Petitioners they are more numerous at every Session of Congress than before— And of late as some of them have died, their widows have begun to Petition, and this day there was a Petition from the Son of a deceased Pensioner praying that the Pension may be continued to him— There were also sundry Petitions from various parts of the Country for the abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia— These are always turned over to the Committee on the District, with a Chairman and a Majority of the Committee Slave-holders; and the House hear no more about them— W. W. Ellsworth of Connecticut this day presented one or two of these Petitions, and with much solemnity of manner said he wished the house to understand, that he concurred entirely in the views and Sentiments of the Petitioners, on this subject, and then moved that the Petition without reading should be referred to the Committee on the District of Columbia— There are Petitions for Appropriations for Roads and Canals, and other works of internal improvement—little encouraged at this time— Resolutions of State and Territorial Legislatures—among which Lucius Lyon, the territorial Delegate from Michigan presented Resolutions of the Legislative Council requesting that a census of the Territory may be taken, and that they may be authorised to hold an extra Session—referred to the Committee on the Territories— Also a Memorial concerning the Southern Boundary of the Territory, in controversy with the State of Ohio—lies on the Table— Mr Gales called me out, and spoke of the manner in which he proposed to print my intended Speech, in the Intelligencer, in such sort that it may be made up into a pamphlet— He gave me as a sample a copy of Mr Wilde’s Speech— Mr Corwin of Ohio called me out and said he believed, if I wished to make my Speech on the deposite question, one of the members from the State of Ohio who voted with the majority would move a reconsideration of the second Resolution to give me the opportunity to speak— I declined for various reasons—one, that I was unwilling to accept a privilege not to be extended to others. Another, that I would be under no obligation, which the member making the offer might reproach me with, if he should dislike my Speech— A third was the useless waste of time in delivering a Speech which would not change one vote, after the question to which it applies has been decided by yeas and nays.—
8. VI. Tuesday.

Morning visit from Mr Lippincott, and four others members of the delegations from the Select and Common Councils of the City of Philadelphia sent with the memorial from those bodies, to explain the evil consequences of the removal of the Public deposites.— At the House, among the Reports of Committees, was a Resolution, by Richard M. Johnson from the Military Committee that in consequence of the time which has elapsed since the establishment of the present system of discipline for the army, and the improvements which have taken place in military science, it is expedient to have a revision of said system, and therefore, that the Secretary of War, be directed to cause a revision thereof to be made, and the same to be reported to Congress at its next Session— This Resolution was read and agreed to by the House without opposition, and without one word of comment— It is a job for General Scott, who has laid this Country under regular contribution, for this same pretence of improved military discipline, for the last twenty-years—ever since the pacification of Ghent—as if military discipline was intended for nothing else but to be mended— Mr Corwin continued his Speech, upon Mardis’s Resolution concerning the deposites in the State-Banks till the expiration of the first hour— Then Cramer continued his Speech upon the commutation Pension Bill, but soon gave way to Mr Polk, who moved to proceed to the orders of the day and then to go into Committee of the whole upon the General
Appropriation Bill. Hubbard of New-Hampshire in the Chair— Polk moved to strike out an addition of 500 dollars to the Chief Clerk in the Department of State, which was done. Vinton from the Committee on Patents moved an Addition of 500 dollars to the machinist, and 300 dollars addition to the Messenger of the Patent Office— Rejected— I moved to strike out the clause, for a temporary Clerk in the Department of State, for one year, for arranging and preserving the Archives of the Department, with a Salary of 1400 Dollars.— This gave rise to a debate which continued till about 4 O’Clock, when the Committee rose, and reported that they had come to no Resolution—the house then adjourned— I addressed the Committee two or three times, on the motion to strike out the appropriation for an additional temporary Clerk, for one year—considering it as a shabby artifice to get in by indirection one Clerk more to transact the business of the Department. Vance moved to suspend the rule for an Amendment.
9. VI. Wednesday.

A man by the name of Cassell came and asked me to recommend him to Overton Carr, Door-keeper of the House, as an Assistant Door-keeper, and shewed me a Letter recommending him, from Daniel Carroll of Duddington— I spoke to Mr Carr, but he said he had no occasion for an assistant— At the House John Bell of Tennessee from the Committee on the Judiciary, reported a Bill, supplementary to the act amendatory of the Copyright Laws—twice read— Mr Corwin continued his Speech for the first hour after the meeting, upon Mardis’s Resolution— After which the House went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union upon the general Appropriation-Bill. The amendment moved yesterday by me to strike out the Appropriation for a temporary additional Clerk in the Department of State for one year was debated till half-past four O’Clock— Several propositions were made to amend the clause: one by John W. Brown of New-York, which after being much discussed he withdrew, upon a motion of H. Binney to strike out the word preserve and insert the words “to make an index” with reference to the papers of the Department— Mr Binney spoke twice in favour of the Appropriation, intimating that he did so, having assented to it in the Committee of Ways and Means— Governor Lincoln made a long Speech in favour of my amendment, and was bitterly replied to, by Hawes of Kentucky and by Mann of New-York— Polk spoke three or four times, and Archer of Virginia made a warm Speech in honour of the Secretary of State Louis M’Lane— I made a final reply after two or three abortive motions for the Committee to rise—the question was taken, and the vote to strike out the clause as amended by Mr Binney’s motion was 89 to 70. The Committee rose, and the House, near 5. adjourned— My mind was deeply moved by these two days of debate.— The immediate object of which was very small, but the principle which it involved I thought of the deepest importance— Within the last five years Congress has been led into and irregular confused mode of connecting with the Appropriation Bills a multitude of other objects, which are surreptitiously introduced to authorize expenditures which Congress would not directly sanction.— I made this motion, as a first step of an attempt to arrest this practice, and to bring the Legislature back to the true principles of making Appropriations— It is an arduous undertaking, and must be perseveringly pursued— The success of the first movement is encouraging; but the evil usage will be constantly returning; and some nice discrimination will be necessary, to avoid excluding small expenditures of no importance, without admitting others— I took Stanbury the Reporter to the National Intelligencer Office, and found upon enquiry that they had no Press-copy ready for me— Mr Gales told me that they could not get my intended Speech into the Newspaper till Saturday Morning.— Evening at Whist.

10. VI. Thursday.— Passed a sleepless Night; the usual consequence of a state of mind, in which I have been for the last two days— At the House, Mr Corwin of Ohio being indisposed and absent from the House, the discussion upon Mr Mardis’s Resolution was postponed till to-morrow; and after some debate there was an Agreement to take up in their order the Resolutions on the Speaker’s table, and to pass those upon which no debate would arise— They were accordingly taken up and a great number of them adopted without opposition. I presented by leave of the House the Petition of Southey Parker which he had brought me this morning, and it was referred to the Committee of Claims.— The Resolution proposed on the 21st. of January by Samuel A. Foot, for the appointment of a Committee to revise the Rules and orders of the House, was adopted and a committee of seven members was ordered, and my Resolution, proposed on the 10th. of February, concerning the limitation of time within which the Committee of Ways and Means should be required to report the Annual Appropriation Bills was at my motion referred to that Committee— My other motion, made on the 21st. of January, for copies of the Instructions to R. Rush, of 6. November 1817. was laid on the table—the Committee of Foreign Relations having obtained from the Department of State, an abstract from the Instructions, containing the order not to receive Presents from Foreign Sovereigns; and the order by the present President of the United States which is dated the 6th. of January 1834—the same day on which he sent the Message to the House, announcing his prohibition to the Officers of the United States abroad, as if he was the first who had given the order— So struts the Jay in borrowed plumage Warren R. Davis of South-Carolina moved three Resolutions 1. That the Powers of the Executive Department of the Federal Government have been increased beyond the authority of the Constitution. 2. That the Powers of the Executive Department of the federal Government, are increasing and ought to be diminished. 3 That the patronage of the President of the United States has increased, is increasing, and ought to be diminished— Most of the Resolutions adopted were Instructions to Committees to enquire into the expediency of measures proposed— This is one of the modes of originating business in the House, convenient only when the proposer of the measure is a member of the Committee which he wishes to instruct. Lucius Lyon, the delegate from the Michigan Territory offered a Resolution that the Secretary of War be requested to communicate to the House the report of Captain Andrew Talcott, of the result of observations made by him during the past Season, for ascertaining the latitude and longitude of several places in the vicinity of the northern boundary of the States of Ohio, Indiana, and Illinois— The motion lies on the Table— The commutation-pension Bill was postponed to next Wednesday the 16th. At Noon the House in Committee of the whole on the Union resumed the Consideration of the General Appropriation Bill— Vance of Ohio had moved on Tuesday to suspend the Rule, for him to propose an amendment containing a whole retrenchment system a reduction of one third upon the Salaries of all the Officers of the Executive Government, and of one fourth upon the pay of members of Congress— He now produced this amendment and it was debated till past four O’Clock— The question was taken by tellers five or six times, and the reduction was in every case rejected, by votes of about 70 to 90. Sometime after 4. O’Clock the Committee rose, and the house adjourned— Coll. George C Washington called me out and wished me to support an Appropriation proposed by the Committee of foreign Affairs for the purchase of President Washington’s papers, for 25000. dollars— In the Evening I
received from the Office of the National Intelligencer the proof of my deposite Speech.
11. VI. Friday.

The Bank of Washington announced this morning that it had suspended Specie Payments— I was belated in revising my Speech— I took it revised to the Office of the National Intelligencer, and gave it to Mr Gales— It is to be published to-morrow Morning— Gales said they were flurried by the stoppage of the Bank of Washington— At the House I found Mr Corwin speaking on Mardis’s Resolution till Noon— He did not finish. Polk moved to suspend the rules for the consideration of private business, to take up the general Appropriation Bill—rejected by yeas and nays 92 to 94. After passing over several Bills, that to provide the payment of claims, for property lost, captured or destroyed, by the enemy, while in the military service of the United States, during the late War with Great-Britain, and the Indian Wars subsequent thereto, and for other purposes, was taken up, and the House went into Committee of the Whole, C. C. Clay in the chair—a debate upon it arose, and continued till near four O’Clock; chiefly between Elisha Whittlesey of Ohio, Chairman of the Committee of Claims, and Benjamin Hardin of Kentucky— The Committee rose without taking the question and the House adjourned— I went into the Senate chamber, where George M. Bibb, Senator from Kentucky was speaking against a motion to reprint the Journals of the Confederation Congress— Ether Shepley of Maine and King of Georgia afterwards spoke—and the Senate adjourned over to Monday.— Warren R. Davis of South-Carolina, asked me for a Letter to some person at Hamburg for James Hamilton junr. son of General Hamilton, the late Governor of that State— Mr Preston in the Senate made the same request— I promise a Letter to John Cuthbert Consul of the United States at Hamburg. After dinner Mr Page, a young man from Virginia brought me a Letter from Coll. Roger Jones his brother in Law— Mr Page is going to Boston. I gave him a Letter to my Son Charles— Dr Lovell, the Surgeon General, was also here, and spoke of the debt due to me, from the second Presbyterian Church of which he promised to send me an account.

12. VI. Saturday.— My Speech, suppressed by the previous Question, was published in the National Intelligencer of this morning. 18 columns of the Paper— When I entered the House Mr Stanbury the Reporter came and intimated to me that there would be a complaint made against me for a breach of the privilege of the House in the Introduction to my Speech in the assertion that the moving of the Previous Question was by agreement concerted, out of the House— But no such complaint was made, nor any notice taken of my introduction. In the House, Mr Corwin of Ohio, finished his Speech upon Mardis’s Resolution— C. C. Clay of Alabama moved to lay the Resolution on the Table— Thomas M. T. M’Kennan of Pennsylvania asked him to withdraw the motion to give him an opportunity to deliver his opinions upon the question.— Clay refused to withdraw his motion— Corwin at the conclusion of his Speech, moved as an Amendment to Mardis’s Resolution, to strike out all after the word resolved, and insert, that the Reasons of the Secretary of the Treasury, for the removal of the Deposites from the Bank of the United States are insufficient, and that it is inexpedient to enact a Law requiring the Secretary of the Treasury to deposite the public moneys in the State Banks— There was then a motion for a Call of the House upon which the yeas and nays were taken—152 for the call to 11. The call was commenced, but was soon suspended at the motion of Elisha Whittlesey, the first hour having expired.— The House proceeded to the orders of the day— The debate was resumed on the Bill for the payment of claims for certain property, lost by capture or destruction by the Enemy during the late War, which was discussed again between Elisha Whittlesey
Benjamin Hardin of Kentucky and several others, till about 3. O’Clock, when the Bill was reported to the House with amendments— The Speaker laid before the House two Letters from the Secretary of War, and the House adjourned— I wrote this morning a Letter to John Cuthbert the Consul of the United States at Hamburg, recommending to him James Hamilton junr. the son of General James Hamilton late Governor of South Carolina, which I gave to Warren R Davis— Young Hamilton goes to Hamburg for a mercantile Education.

13. VI. Sunday.— Heard at the Presbyterian Church Mr Smith from Amos 4.12—[“]Therefore, thus will I do unto thee, O Israel: and because I will do this unto thee prepare to meet thy God, O Israel.” The comment of the preacher, a very solemn one was upon the words, prepare to meet thy God— Mr Chambers of Pennsylvania, and Mr Wardwell of New-York, members of the House of Representatives, were in my Pew— After dinner at St. John’s Church, Mr Hawley read prayers for the second Sunday after Easter, and preached from Revelation 21.7. [“]He that overcometh, shall inherit all things, and I will be his God, and he shall be my Son”— The remainder of the day was much engrossed in revising my suppressed Speech, as printed in the National Intelligencer yesterday. I received this morning a Letter from N. F. Williams at Baltimore, requesting a few copies of it in pamphlet form, and a Baltimore Patriot of yesterday, in which it is already noticed— This Evening I received a note from Mr Gales, mentioning that they had received an order to print fifty thousand copies of it in the pamphlet form— I had also this day to revise Mr Stanbury’s minutes upon my last Speech, in Committee of the whole, upon my motion to strike out of the general Appropriation Bill, the clause to smuggle an additional Clerk into the Department of State, under colour of employing him only for one year to assort and preserve the papers in the Department—

14. VI. Monday.— In the Globe of this morning there is an Editorial Article headed Mr Adams and the Speaker, evidently written or dictated by the Speaker Andrew Stevenson himself— He controverts none of the facts stated in the Introduction to my Speech, but throws the blame of all his abuses in the Chair upon the House, and denies that there, was any collusion between him and John Y. Mason to give him the floor— The Article closes with a promise to take up the substance of my Speech hereafter, but expresses an opinion that the Speech itself should be prosecuted as a libel—adding—“but we are no lawyers.” In the House the day was consumed in receiving Memorials and Petitions; and Resolutions, and proceedings for and against the removal of the deposites, and the Bank of the United States— Benjamin Gorham presented a Memorial from Boston, praying for the establishment of a Warehousing System; referred to the Committee of the whole House—before which there is a Bill for that purpose— I presented a Memorial of the President, Officers and board of Managers of the Howard Institution in the City of Washington, praying for an Act of incorporation—referred to the Committee on the District of Columbia— Huntington of Connecticut presented a petition from that State praying a Law granting an appeal or writ of error, from the Circuit to the Supreme Court of the United States in all cases where the matter in dispute or the sum for which judgment is recovered exceeds 500 dollars— There are many other Petitions to the same effect— The Speaker presented Resolutions of the Legislature of Pennsylvania, calling upon Congress to act definitely on the subject of weights and measures, by establishing with as little delay as possible the necessary Standards, and furnishing each of the State Governments, with authentic copies of the same—referred to the Committee of Ways and Means. Among the multitude of Bank and deposite Memorials T. Burges of
Rhode-Island presented one from the County of Providence, complaining of distress, signed by 3400 names, and D. J. Pearce presented a Counter-Memorial, which he moved should be read as it was— Burges then moved that the Memorial presented by him should be read, but the Speaker looking steadily to another part of the house, did not or would not hear Burges. He repeated the motion five or six times, with a voice as loud as he could raise, but the Speaker took no notice of him, called for Connecticut and went successively through all the States as far as North-Carolina, when the proceedings of a meeting at Morgantown, Burke County, North Carolina, in favour of a restoration of the deposites and a recharter of the Bank of the United States, presented by James Graham, occasioned an incident. There was an insulting allusion to an expression used by Forsyth of Georgia, in a recent debate in the Senate, of contempt for Pot-house Memorials— They said that his Speech coming from so courteous a person could be accounted for only upon the supposition that it was delivered under extraordinary exhilaration, but whether proceeding from the Pot-house or the Palace, they did not know. James M. Wayne of Georgia, asked Mr Graham to withdraw this memorial but he declined— Wayne then moved that it should not be received, on account of the insult contained in it upon a member of the Senate— At the motion of M’Kinley of Alabama, Wayne’s Motion, lies on the table till next Monday.— M’Kim of Baltimore presented to the House Instructions to him, from a portion of his Constituents, to vote for the restoration of the deposites to the Bank of the United States— Evans of Maine, in presenting a Memorial from Gardner and Pittston in that State, for the restoration of the Deposites and the recharter of the Bank of the United States, moved its reference to the Committee of Ways and Means, with Instructions to report a Resolution, declaring that a Bank established by authority of Congress is necessary and ought to be established— It was near five when the House adjourned— I was informed that Mr Dennis a member of the House from Maryland was extremely ill, and not expected to survive the day.
15. V:30. Tuesday.

At the meeting of the House this morning John T Stoddert a member of the House from Maryland, announced in the usual form the decease of his Colleague Littleton Purnell Dennis, last Evening— He adverted in a few short Sentences to the principal incidents in his life, and pronounced a compendious-eulogy upon his character. The usual Resolutions followed—1. That the members of the House would attend the funeral of the deceased at 12. O’Clock to-morrow. 2. That a Committee of arrangements should be appointed, to superintend the funeral, and 3. That the members of the House will testify their respect for the memory of L. P. Dennis, by wearing crape 30 days— The order for a message to the Senate was not moved but went of course, and the House immediately adjourned. I walked home and found a note from the foreman of the National Intelligencer Office, with the first sheet of my suppressed Speech in pamphlet form; with a request to me to return it as soon as convenient. I revised it accordingly and wrote also to my nephews Lieutenant Thomas B. Adams, at Pittsburgh, and to Isaac Hull Adams the Cadet at West-Point— And a Letter to Commodore Rodgers, enclosing one of Introduction to the Duke of Sussex for Coll. A. P. Hayne.— This being the third Tuesday in April was the day to which the Antimasonic Meeting at the Capitol had been adjourned— I called at Mr Larned’s, and took with me, Mr John Bailey of Massachusetts who is now in this City. The meeting was at the chamber of the Committee of Foreign Affairs— There were three or four Members from Pennsylvania, and as many from New-York present, but there was no specific proposition before the meeting, and it ran into a
more desultory conversation— Mr Clarke of Pennsylvania proposed that the members should communicate to each other the names of persons in the respective States with whom correspondence could be opened if necessary— Adjourned about 9. O’Clock to meet again if the Chairman see fit to call a meeting.

16. V:30. Wednesday.— Captain Aulick of the Navy met me in the Pennsylvania Avenue, and said Commodore Hull had mentioned to him, that there was a person at my house, who would wish to go as Captain’s clerk to sea in a public ship— I supposed it was William C. Greenleaf. Captain Aulick said he was going out in the Brandywine Frigate to the Pacifick to take command of a Ship now there; and would willingly take as his Clerk the person who had been recommended by Commodore Hull.— My Son John had proposed to William C. Greenleaf to go, and he requested a day or two for consideration of the offer.— This morning as I was going to the Capitol, I met Captain Aulick, who enquired if I could give him an answer— I was not ready, but promised to send him one to-morrow— The House met at noon and the funeral obsequies were performed in the usual manner, over the remains of Littleton Purnell Dennis, a member of the House from Maryland— The Chaplains of the two houses performed their respective Services—a prayer by Mr Stockton, and a short discourse by Mr Hatch— The President and his Secretaries came in when the ceremonies were nearly over— I rode to and from the grave-yard with Mr Lay— And then from the Capitol home alone— At the receiving vault Mr Stockton read the Episcopal Church funeral Service— The weather was at high Summer heat— At home I answered two invitations, which have long been on my table from literary Societies at the Colleges of Geneva in New-York and of Amherst, Massachusetts, to deliver Addresses at their annual Commencements next August— I declined both— Wrote also a short Letter to Nicholas Biddle— I dined with Mr Isaac C. Bates, member of the House from the District of Massachusetts, and with his fellow lodgers at Hyatt’s— They are chiefly from Massachusetts, Connecticut and Vermont— Governor Lincoln was there, and there was much political conversation— I sent this morning the first revised sheet of my suppressed Speech to the National Intelligencer Office, and received from it the second and third proof Sheets—

17. V:30. Thursday.— At the House, Leonard Jarvis of Maine twice moved for leave to offer a Resolution, for the appointment of a Select Committee to investigate the causes of the suspension of Specie Payments by the Washington and Patriotic Banks in this City, the Farmers and Mechanics Bank at Georgetown, and the Bank of Alexandria, but he could not obtain a vote of two thirds for the suspension of the Rule— The House refused also by a vote of 113 to 49. to consider a Resolution, offered this day last week by Thomas Chilton of Kentucky, calling upon the President of the United States for his plan of a National Bank— W. W. Ellsworth from the Committee on the Judiciary, reported a Bill—N 431. to authorize a Writ of Error in certain cases relating to Patent rights, to the Supreme Court of the United States—read twice and referred to the Committee of the whole on the State of the Union— Lewis Williams from the Committee on the Territories, reported a Bill, N. 432 to authorize an extra Session of the Legislative Council of the Territory of Michigan—read twice, and referred to the committee of the whole, to which is referred the Bill N 362 for taking a Census of the Territories of Michigan and Arkansas. C. F. Mercer from the Committee on Roads and Canals, made a Report on the Memorial
of the Canal Company, praying for a further Subscription to their Stock—read, ordered to be printed, and referred to the Committee of the whole, to which is referred Bill, N. 94. to authorize such an additional Subscription— Andrew Stewart moved the printing of 3000 extra copies of the Report— The motion lies on the table— Hubbard from the Committee on the Militia, reported a Bill, N. 434. to organize arm and establish a uniform militia throughout the United States, and to provide for its discipline— Read twice and referred to the Committee of the whole House on the Union. Duncan of Illinois obtained leave by unanimous consent to move that 3000 additional copies be printed, of the Letter, report and map furnished the War Department by Lieutt. Allen who accompanied H. R. Schoolcraft to, and beyond the Sources of the Mississippi River in 1832. communicated last Saturday to the House— Mardis’s Resolution was taken up and C. C. Clay withdrew his motion that it be laid on the table— Corwin’s amendment recurred and was debated till the expiration of the hour— The Bill N. 402. to pay for claims for property, lost captured or destroyed by the enemy while in the military service of the United States, during the late War, was ordered to be engrossed for a third reading to-morrow— The commutation pension Bill, N. 256 was postponed till next Thursday— Committee of the whole on the Union, upon the general Appropriation Bill— Joseph Vance of Ohio’s Amendment for reducing the Salaries of all the Officers in the Public Departments was resumed, and the question taken upon those of the Commissioner of the Land Office, and of all his clerks, both of which were rejected. Very little further progress was made in the Bill, when the Committee rose and the House adjourned.

The President of the United States this day sent to the Senate a Protest, against their Resolution, of censure upon him for his recent interferences with the public revenues; and he calls upon them to enter his protest upon their Journals— Great excitement— Poindexter moved that it should not be received— Clay, Webster and Preston are absent— The correction and revisal of the second and third sheets of my suppressed Speech absorbed all my time at home.
18. V:45. Friday.

Archer from the Committee of foreign Relations, reported a Bill for continuing the Neapolitan Treaty-Commission—read twice and referred to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— Duncan’s motion for printing 3000 extra copies of Lieutenant Allen’s report and map was adopted— James P. Heath of Maryland, immediately after the reading of the Journal offered a Resolution that the Secretary of the Treasury be directed to deposite in the Bank of the United States and its branches, from the first day of May next, and until the expiration of its charter, all the accrueing revenues of the Government.— Objection made— Heath moved the suspension of the Rule, and Lewis Williams called for the yeas and nays. 83 to 89.— Governor Lincoln offered a Resolution calling upon the Postmaster General for information concerning the employment, compensation and duties of certain Clerks—and upon objection being made, he asked suspension of the rule, for which there were only 76 votes. Jarvis moved and carried by a vote of 151 to 22 the suspension of the rule to offer the Resolution of enquiry into the causes of the failure of several of the Banks of the District, and into their Condition— Ben Hardin moved an amendment extending the enquiry to the condition of the Bank of the Metropolis; which gave rise to a debate till the hour expired— Jarvis moved to suspend the rule, and continue the discussion, but the house refused— Polk moved that the question of reconsideration upon the rejection of the Bill for the relief of David Kilbourn should be postponed till next Friday—which being agreed to, Polk then moved the suspension of the rul of private business, to take up the general Appropriation Bill— M’Kim thereupon called for the yeas and nays, which were 91 to 66. not two thirds and the motion failed— The Speaker laid before the House, two
Letters from the Secretary of War— Henry A. Wise asked the consent of the House, and then a suspension of the Rules, to offer three Resolutions, in the face of the President’s Protest, sent yesterday to the Senate—declaring the custody and controul of the Public monies to be in Congress and subject to their Legislation— Then there was a call of the House, which lasted three quarters of an hour, when it was given up, and the vote upon suspending the rule was upon yeas and nays 104 to 93—not two thirds— Then Balie Peyton of Tennessee moved to suspend the rule of private business, for him to offer three Resolutions, counterparts to those offered by Wise—declaring that the President, in his late proceedings relating to the revenue had not assumed unlawful powers— That the Senate by their late Resolution of censure upon the President, have infringed upon the rightful and legitimate powers and prerogatives of the House of Representatives; and that Congress have the power by Law, to select the places of depositing the public money, and providing for its safe-keeping— The vote to suspend was 96 to 91. all the opposition voting for the suspension— Peyton withdrew his Resolutions— The day was thus consumed, so that the House barely reached the Bill for the relief of Susan Decatur and others. I went into the Senate chamber, and heard Benjamin Watkins Leigh of Virginia against the President’s Protest—an easy and handsome Speaker—
19. V:30. Saturday.

At the House Richard M. Johnson from the Committee on Military Affairs reported a Bill N 440. for printing 5000 copies of a system of cavalry tactics for the use of the Militia—with a report— The Bill was twice read and referred to the Committee of the whole on the Union— Lewis Williams from the Committee on the Territories reported a Bill 441. increasing the Salaries of the judges of the United States for the Territories of Michigan, Arkansas and Florida—read twice and committed to the Committee of the whole on the Union— Augustin S. Clayton of Georgia, moved a suspension of the Rules, for him to offer a Resolution for the appointment of a retrenchment Committee— The rule was suspended by a vote of 127 to 16.— The motion was for retrenchment in all the Executive Departments— It was moved to extend the enquiry to the pay and mileage of Members of Congress— Clayton accepted the amendment— The vote on the Resolution itself was taken, by consent, and carried—188 to 2— Wise of Virginia then offered anew his Resolutions presented yesterday, and then not received— They were now somewhat modified— He moved for the suspension of the Rule—and for the yeas and nays, which were 99 to 91. not two thirds— Peyton of Tennessee then reproduced his Resolutions, yesterday presented, against the Senate, and in honour of the President of the United States, and moved the suspension of the rule—the vote was 95 to 95—exactly balanced— Allen of Ohio asked permission to give an explanation of his vote on these Resolutions yesterday, in consequence of some publication in one of this Morning’s Newspapers— Not allowed— Then the Bill for compensating sufferers in the late War, and another were passed at the third reading— House in Committee of the whole, Connor in the Chair— Bill for the relief of Susan Decatur and others— Hubbard made a Speech of two hours in support of the Bill; after which Hardin of Kentucky, and Parker of New-Jersey sent Amendments to be discussed hereafter— Then came up the Bill for the relief of the legal Representatives of Richard W. Meade— There was an attempt to get them out of the Committee into the House, but it failed— It was about four when the Committee rose, reported progress, and asked leave to sit again— Then the House adjourned— Mr Samuel A. Turner of Scituate called upon me this Evening, about the projected Canal at the mouth of Taunton river— A fair spoken man, one year a member of the Senate of Massachusetts, chosen by the Legislature, though a Jackson man, to exclude an Anti-mason.
20. V:30. Sunday.

Just as I was going to Church Edward Wyer called and paid me a visit, to wail over the condition of Public Affairs—but he had nothing of any importance to say— In the Morning at the Presbyterian Church, a Stranger preached from John 14.27. “Peace, I leave with you, my peace I give unto you: not as the world giveth, give I unto you. Let not your heart be troubled, neither let it be afraid.”— Mr Smith was present; and gave notice that he would administer the Communion, this day fortnight— After dinner at St. John’s Church Mr Olney read the Evening service, for the third Sunday after Easter, and preached from Romans 10.16. “But they have not all obeyed the gospel.” A discourse of very sharp reproof to his Auditory— Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith were here this Evening.— In the Protest which the President sent last Thursday to the Senate, against a Resolution of censure passed by that body upon his interference with the revenue, he affirms that their course of proceeding in that case was unprecedented— It is true, that no such Resolution ever passed before: it is also true that no such Revolution ought ever to pass that body; but precisely similar Resolutions have been introduced and debated on more than one occasion— I looked into Gales and Seaton’s Register of Debates in Congress. Vol: 2 the Session of Congress of 1825 and 1826 for John Branch’s Resolution concerning Executive Powers— The Resolutions are two—of 30. March 1826—page 404.— See Speech of Nathaniel Macon—24. April page 634— Johnson of Kentucky page 638— The Resolutions laid on the Table. 27. April 1826. page 642. by a vote of 23 to 21.— Benton, Johnson of Kentucky, Kane, King of Alabama, Macon, Van Buren—Hugh L. White, and L. Woodbury, all voted against laying on the table, and to sustain the Resolutions— Similar Resolutions were introduced by Christopher Gore, in 1813. upon the appointment of the Ministers for the Russian Mediation Mission— They were first arrested by the close of the Session of Congress—were renewed at the opening of the next Session, and after long debate, and transfer from the Executive to the Legislative Journal were at last indefinitely postponed— All the federalists then voted for them— The Parties in the Senate have always voted for or against these Resolutions according as they supported or opposed the President.
21. V:30. Monday.

At the House, it being the day for the reception of Petitions— The Memorial from Gardiner and Pittston, Maine presented last Monday had precedence for consideration.— George Evans opened the discussion with a Speech of two hours, nearly, and when he finished F. O. J. Smith moved to postpone the further Consideration of the subject till next Monday— Wise moved his Resolutions as additional Instructions to the Committee of Ways and Means, to those proposed by Evans’s Resolution— This, the Speaker declared not the be in order; but Evans accepted Wise’s Resolutions as a Modification of his own, and then Wise made an anti-Jackson Speech— Peyton then moved his Resolutions as Amendment of Evans’s, and as a substitute for th portion of them as modified by Wise’s additions— This the Speaker declared out of order, but he allowed Peyton to make his Speech— One of his Resolution was a lumping justification of the President’s financeerings, and the other a charge against the Senate, of usurping the rights of the House of Representatives; and he said he offered them because he thought the House had nothing to do with the quarrels between the President, and the Senate— Turrell of New-York moved to lay the whole farrago, on the Table; upon which Evans withdrew Wise’s Resolutions which he had accepted— For he
wished the question to be taken upon his Resolution alone.— Peyton’s Amendment fell, of course— Boon of Indiana moved that the Memorial, and the motion of Evans, should be laid on the Table— Carried by yeas and nays 108 to 90. and the House adjourned— Not a Petition or Memorial could be presented; and the day was thus trifled away— I went into the Senate chamber, where they were debating on the Presidents Protest, and upon certain alterations of it proposed by his private Secretary— He had sent in this morning an explanatory paper. Messrs. Clay, Webster, Preston and Poindexter, late absent, were in their Seats. Clay thanked me for my suppressed Speech, which he said he had read with much pleasure— Mr S. A. Turner called upon me this Evening, with Messrs. Handy, Peters and Waters— Evening visit also from Mr John Bailey— My wife and Mary spent the Evening at Mr Frye’s.
22. V:30. Tuesday.

Mr Turner called on my this morning, and I went with him to the War Department, where I introduced him to the Secretary of War, and afterwards to J. L. Edwards the Commissioner of Pensions— I left with the Secretary of War a Letter and papers from Eliphez Thayer— Mr Turner rode with me to the Capitol— I found Cambreleng flourishing upon the Petition of 235 Poles, for a grant of land, which at his motion was referred to the Committee on the Public Lands— A. S. Clayton from the retrenchment Committee, consisting of him, Joseph Vance, Samuel Beardsley, Edward T. White, James I. M’Kay, William Baylies and James H. Gholson, reported a Resolution authorising the Committee to send for persons and papers, which was agreed to by the House— Jarvis called up his Resolution for enquiries into the causes of the breaking up of sundry Banks in the District, which he had modified to include enquiry into the condition of the Bank of the Metropolis.— Beardsley made a Speech against instituting any enquiry into the affairs of the Metropolis, or other depository Banks. This led to a debate till the hour expired— Gamble of Georgia had moved to suspend the rule which confines the reception of Memorials and Petitions, after the first 30 days of the Session, to Mondays, for the purpose of receiving and referring memorials and Petitions without debate—but the House refused. The Orders of the day were called— Polk presented a Report and Bill N. 443. regulating the deposite of the public monies in certain local Banks. The Bill was twice read and Polk moved its reference to the Committee of the whole, on the state of the Union— Ewing moved that the whole, together with sundry sayings of the President be referred to a select Committee of one member from each State, with Instructions to Report a National Bank— The Speaker declared this motion not in order— I instantly made it a question, and the Speaker recanted, and admitted Ewing’s motion, but said he could not discuss it— I questioned that too, and the Speaker allowed Ewing to discuss. Polk soon made a question of order which the Speaker decided against him— He then implored Ewing to let the Bill lie over, and bargained with him to let the Cumberland road Bill come up next after the general Appropriation Bill—upon which Ewing gave up the floor— Burges moved an Instruction to make the Banks pay interest upon the deposites— Binney and Stewart opposed this and Burges withdrew his motion— The Speaker laid before the house a Letter from the Secretary of the Treasury with the returns of Commerce and Navigation to the 30th. of September 1833— Ten thousand copies ordered to be printed— Also a Letter from the Secretary of War, with copies of the reports and surveys of harbours on lake Erie; called for by the House on the 10th instt.—referred to the Committee of Commerce— Then followed the Committee of the whole House on the State of the Union Henry Hubbard in the Chair—on the general Appropriation Bill.— Long tiresome debate; and very disorderly proceedings, the Speaker being absent from the House. Upon some question it was found there was no Quorum voting; Hubbard chairman of the Committee of the whole called Jesse Speight of North-Carolina to the Chair to act as Speaker, and reported to him the fact that there was no Quorum in Committee of the whole. Evans of Maine, moved
to adjourn, which was rejected by yeas and nays 53 to 87—twenty members more than a Quorum— Speight then as Speaker left the chair and Hubbard as chairman of the Committee of the whole resumed it, without any vote of the House— The debate dragged along till the Committee was again found without a Quorum— Hubbard again called Speight to the Chair as Speaker, and reported to him the fact of no Quorum in Committee— I moved to adjourn, which was rejected by yeas and nays 39 to 86. only five more than a Quorum— I moved a Call of the House. Speight refused to put the question. I appealed from his decision as Speaker, he refused to entertain the motion, and without vote of the House again left the Chair, which was again resumed by Hubbard as Chairman of the Committee of the whole—but from that time no Quorum could be formed; several of the Minority keeping their Seats, or passing without the Bar, that they might not be counted, at the vote by Tellers—so as that a Quorum should be made— The majority, finding at last that they could not thus drive the Bill through the Committee of the whole gave it up. Evans renewed his motion to adjourn, and the House was adjourned, without even reporting from the Committee of the whole their third failure to make a Quorum— In these proceedings, every thing was disorder and confusion—all owing to the absence of the Speaker from the Chair, and a dogged determination of the Administration majority, to force the Bill through the Committee of the whole.

23. V:30. Wednesday. Met Coll. Thomas H. Perkins, and Mr and Mrs Charles P. Curtis, at the House of Representatives.— Immediately after the reading of the Journal of yesterday I moved that it should be amended at three different places.— The first and second by making it conformable to the Precedents on the Journal of the first Session of the last Congress of 20. June 1832. p. 906 of 21. June p. 909. of 6. July p. 1100–1101–1102. Upon this after a debate of about 3. hours my motion was at the motion of Boon of Indiana laid on the table by yeas and nays 100 to 89 I then moved another amendment, stating the fact that the acting Speaker, Speight of North-Carolina, refused to receive a motion by my for a Call of the House, and upon my taking an Appeal from the decision, refused to entertain the Appeal. Boon immediately moved to lay this motion on the Table; but the vote by yeas and nays was 94 to 95. upon which another debate of an hour and a half arose, and after an ineffectual motion by Wilde of Georgia to adjourn; the motion was renewed, by Joseph M. Harper of New-Hampshire to lay my amendment on the table and carried by yeas and nays 98 to 90. It was near 4 O’Clock— These were all close administration party votes— Boon’s second motion to lay mine on the table would have succeeded but the wrong was so glaring that Cage, Leonard Jarvis, Seaborn Jones, Parker, A. H. Shepperd, and James M. Wayne, shook their shackles and voted to allow me a hearing.— At the final vote Jarvis and Parker returned to their allegiance, and with Bouldin who came in, and had not been present at the prior votes carried the last against me— The Speaker whose absence from the House yesterday was the primary cause of all the disorder had not the Spirit or the Candour to acknowledge the wrong of his Substitutes, and attempted directly in the face of Hatsell to defend their arbitrary proceedings as conformable to the Lex-Parliamentaria. Richard M. Johnson asked leave to offer a Resolution, that to commence from to-morrow, the general Appropriation Bills, the Cumberland Road Bill, and two or three others should be made the special order for ever day excepting Saturdays for private business, Mondays for Petitions, and the first hour of every day— Objection made he moved to suspend the Rule, to allow him to offer the Resolution— Question taken by yeas and nays 108 to 83. not two thirds. The House adjourned at the motion of Polk between 4 and 5— I was exceedingly exhausted, having repeatedly addressed the House in support of my motions to amend the Journal— Evening idle at whist— Despatched about 100 suppressed Speeches— Sir Charles R. Vaughan gave a Ball— St. George’s day.
24. V:30. Thursday.— The Speaker of the British House of Commons has no power to call to the Chair a substitute to take his place— Thus speaks the Rolliad

lg.l: “There Cornwall sits, and O, unhappy fate,
Must sit forever, through the long debate.——
Like sad Prometheus, fasten’d to his rock,
In vain he looks for pity to the Clock.”

div.p: This privilege of placing a counterfeit Speaker in the Chair, is an abuse here, and ought not to be tolerated— The mock Speaker is under no responsibility, whatever, and has continual temptation to disorder, as was so grossly experienced the day before yesterday. This morning at the House, Mardis’s Resolution with Corwin’s amendment was taken up and M’Kennan spoke till the first hour expired— Archer, Chairman of the Committee of foreign Relations, reported a Bill to authorise the Secretary of State to purchase the Papers of General Washington—read twice and referred to the Committee of the whole House on the state of the Union— Revolutionary Pension Bill, the special order of the day, postponed to next Wednesday— Several Bills passed at the third reading.— Message from the Senate announcing that they had passed a joint Resolution, to provide for watering the Pennsylvania Avenue— The House went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, and took up the Appropriation Bills, for the Civil and Diplomatic expenses of Government. H. Hubbard in the Chair. A long debate followed, upon several amendments proposed by James I. M’Kay of North-Carolina, and by me— M’Kay moved to strike out two items for a clerk in the Topographical bureau, and a clerk in the clothing bureau— But the chief debate was on my motion to strike out an item of additional or temporary Clerk-hire in the Office of Commissioner of Pensions—of 5000 dollars— My object was to call on the Secretary of War, for information what was the cause of the want of this additional Clerk-hire— The real cause was the senseless substitution of the deposite State Banks, instead of the Bank of the United States and its branches for the payment of Pensions— The debate was maintained by Polk, Cambreleng, Sutherland and Chilton, M’Kay, Hardin, Foot, Filmore and myself, but the Committee refused to strike out the item— They proceeded in the Bill to an item of 31731 dollars 44 cents of additional clerk-hire in the Post Office Department when B. Hardin moved that the Committee should rise, which after some time they did— Polk moved to suspend the Rules, for him to offer a Resolution to make the general Appropriation Bill, the standing order of every day, Saturday’s excepted, after 12 O’Clock— The House without deciding the question, about 6 O’Clock adjourned— My wife and Mary spent the Evening at Mr Frye’s.

25. V:30. Friday.— At the House, on Jarvis’s Resolution, to enquire into the Causes of the breaking of the Banks in the District of Columbia, Hardin spoke till the expiration of the hour— Polk moved a suspension of the Rule of private business, to go into a Committee of the whole House upon the general Appropriation Bill, which by Whittlesey of Ohio’s agreeing to it was carried by a vote of more than two thirds— Governor Lincoln made a Speech of an hour and a half, for striking out the item of 31731 dollars 44 cents and censuring the administration of the Post-Office. Pope of Kentucky took up warmly the cause of the Postmaster General— Hardin, Evans of Maine Parker of New-Jersey, Polk, and Horace Everett—followed in the discussion— Connor of North-Carolina, Chairman of the Post-Office Committee gave explanations respecting the affairs of the Office, followed by Chilton— The amendment was long debated— The item of additional Clerk-hire for 1833
was retained— L. Lincoln moved to reduce it to 15000. dollars, but the motion was rejected— Hardin gave a character of the Postmaster General Barry, as an honest, good, easy man, whose greatest fault was that he could never say no, to any one— Ewing of Indiana told a Story of an Hostler at Bloomfield, receiving a Commission as Postmaster which he could not read; upon which Hannegan, another member from Indiana, declared there were no such cases in his district— Adjourned after 5. O’Clock

26. V:30. Saturday. At the House I called up the Petition of the Inhabitants of Wareham, for the improvement of their river, with a map which had been presented and referred, but not acted upon at the last Congress— It was now received, and referred to the Committee on Roads and Canals.— Lingering quorum. Resolution from the Senate for watering the Pennsylvania Avenue reported by the Committee on the District of Columbia without amendment— Chinn moved to suspend the rule, and take it up for consideration— I called for the yeas and nays, which were 84 to 54. not two thirds— Ratliff Boon asked the suspension of the Rule; to take up his Resolution for the adjournment of Congress on Saturday the 31st. of May; and for the yeas and nays which were 91 to 57—not two thirds— Polk, Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means moved to suspend the rule of private business to take up the general Appropriation Bill—92 to 56—not two thirds— Then came private business— The vote rejecting the Bill for the relief of David Kilbourn was reconsidered, and the Bill was postponed to the first Monday of December next— The Bill for the relief of Edmund Brooke was postponed till next Friday— One private Bill was passed to be engrossed for a third reading, and finally upon the Bill for the relief of Susan Decatur and others there was a long straggling debate— Several amendments proposed and rejected, one adopted, and the Bill was at last reported to the house— The vote was carried by Tellers, and I went through arm in arm with Polk, much to the amusement of the House— Connor, Chairman of the Committee of the Whole, asked leave to sit again upon the Bill for the relief of Margaret C. Meade, Administratrix, which was granted. Stansbury the Reporter gave me his minutes of my first remarks in the debate of last Wednesday, with a somewhat argumentative claim of contribution for reporting it— The Senate were not in Session, and several of the Senators were in the Lobby of the House— I spoke with Bell, of New-Hampshire, Chambers, Grundy, Southard and Webster— Mr S. A. Turner was at the House and told me he should go in the Stage at 2. O’Clock this afternoon homewards. The House adjourned about four O’Clock— Weather turning cold.

27. V:30. Sunday.— Wintry gale, cold and clear— Morning at the Presbyterian Church: heard Mr Smith from Psalm 78.8. “and might not be, as their fathers, a stubborn, and rebellious generation; a generation that set not their heart aright, and whose Spirit was not steadfast with God.”— In the afternoon, at St. John’s Church, Mr Hawley read the Evening service, for the fourth Sunday after Easter, and preached from Romans 14.1. [“]Him that is weak in the Faith receive ye, but not to doubtful disputations.”— The publication and distribution of my suppressed Speech absorbs my time to such excess, that it usurps upon my Correspondence, my Journal, and my Memory. I receive Letters every day which I find it impossible to answer— Several this morning. It occupied much of the day, to make out the list of persons to whom I send copies of my Speech—and to revise Stanbury’s Report of my Observations in the House on the Appropriation Bill last Wednesday. Among the Letters received this morning, was one from Jonas Humbert Senr, a Baker in New-York, four pages folio. He appears to be a Politician, Philosopher Theologian and Patriot. A Letter from John W. Foster a Bookseller at Portsmouth, New-Hampshire, enclosing a Prospectus for the publication of Sermons by
Nathan Parker D.D. of that place— One from Thomas P Beal of Kingston in Plymouth County, Massachusetts concerning the claim of Ebenezer Lobdell—and one from Richard Adams of Kensington near Philadelphia, asking me to send him copies of sundry public documents, and one of my own Speech— I took from the Library a Suetonius and Thomson’s English translation of that author, for a passage in the life of Vespasian, ch. 23
28. V. Monday.

Before the meeting of the House, H. Binney shewed me a Letter from John Sergeant, concerning the proceedings of the Bank investigation committee at Philadelphia— When the House met, the Clerk, Walter S. Franklin, at the motion of Mr Binney obtained leave of absence for four or five days on account of the death of his father. Immediately after the Journal was read the Speaker gave the floor to Thomas H. Hall on a Memorial from the County of Edgecombe in that State, presented by him this day fortnight.— He made a very tedious Speech of two hours, and then moved that the papers should be printed and lie on the table. The memorial from Burke County was also at the motion of Mr Graham laid on the Table. The Speaker then called Georgia, and Roger L. Gamble made some remarks on a memorial from Savannah against the removal of the deposites which he had presented on the 14th. instt.— The memorial was now read, and after his Speech upon it was laid on the table and ordered to be printed— Edward T. White presented a deposite Memorial from Louisiana, with some pungent remarks on the present condition of affairs— Osgood asked leave of the House, to make a Speech upon a memorial from Lowell which he presented; but the House refused to hear him and adjourned about 3. O’Clock— Rice Garland, the new member from Louisiana in the place of Judge Bullard was sworn and took his Seat. Warren R. Davis introduced to me, Mr Wilson, late Governor of South-Carolina. After the adjournment I went into the Senate chamber, and heard George M. Bibb, a Senator from Kentucky finish a Speech, begun last week, Friday, upon a motion by him, that the Protest of the President of the United States, against a Resolution of the Senate censuring him, be not received— Mr Southard spoke to me of an Article in the Globe, charging him with perjury; and asked me if I thought he ought to notice it. I said no. He spoke also of a proposed appointment of a Committee of the Senate, to investigate the Affairs of the Bank of the United States, and said he had been asked if he would serve as Chairman of such Committee—and that Forsyth was willing to be one of the Committee— Edward Darlington a member of the House from Pennsylvania was here this morning with a friend of his named Sharp and Mr Silsbee called in the Evening with Mr Devereux of Salem, and his nephew of the same name.
29. V.30. Tuesday

Call at the National Intelligencer Office, to return a package of Speeches uncovered, and ask for a number, packed to be despatched— Mr Gales spoke to me concerning the state of the Patriotic Bank, and I mentioned to him the claim of Stansbury the Reporter upon me for reporting my Speeches in the debate of last Wednesday— He desired me to refer Stansbury to him— I conversed with the Speaker upon my purpose to give notice that I should ask leave of the House to-morrow to introduce a Bill; but he did not approve of it and said that by the rules
of the House it could not be done— After the reading of the Journal I rose to give notice of my intention, to ask leave of the House to introduce a Bill to-morrow—but the Speaker said I was not entitled to the floor, and the house would not grant it— Governor Lincoln asked leave to offer a Resolution of enquiry of the Postmaster General, about the number, names and duties of the Clerks and Agents of the Department— Objection being made, Mr Lincoln moved a suspension of the rule, and called for the yeas and nays— The motion was carried, and the Resolution was received. 102 to 50. It was to lay over a day— Mr Lincoln asked again the suspension of the rules, that it might be considered now. I asked for the yeas and nays, which were 111 to 68. not two thirds, and the Resolution lies over— At Noon the orders of the day were called up— Campbell P. White asked to take up the Bill 255. regulating the value of certain foreign silver coins, but on a question from me, withdrew his motion— The general Appropriation Bill was taken up in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, H. Hubbard in the Chair, and progress in it slowly made, till the Committee rose after some discussion of an amendment, proposed by Dudley Selden of New-York, without deciding upon it.— The House adjourned after 5. O’Clock— Evening visit from Joseph Blunt.— My wife and Mary called at Mrs Tudor’s and Mrs Cutts’s.— Fancy Ball at Joseph M. White’s.
30. V. Wednesday.

Morning call, from Mr Baïley, and Mr Jackson— Conversation with them upon the condition of Anti-masonry, in our own State of Massachusetts, and in others— At the House, immediately after the reading of the Journal, I gave notice of my intention to ask leave of the House to-morrow, to introduce a Bill prohibiting the Corporations of the Cities in the District from issuing promissory Notes or Bills of any denomination less than ten dollars.— The Speaker might have told me, as he did yesterday that I was not entitled to the floor; but he did not, and my notice was given with leave of the House— By the rigid rules of the House, every member is so hemmed in that he cannot open his lips without leave obtained by a formal vote— Bell of Tennessee from the Committee on the judiciary, reported a Bill N. 455. further to amend the judicial system of the United States, (by extending the Circuit Courts)—read twice, and committed to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— M’Kennan of Pennsylvania, finished his Speech upon Corwin’s amendment to Mardis’s Resolution; for which he was indulged with 20 minutes beyond the expiration of the hour— Galbraith of Pennsylvania then took the floor for to-morrow. Then a Resolution of enquiry offered yesterday by C. F. Mercer for a paper concerning the Potowmack Bridge was taken up and adopted— The House went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union. A Bill, regulating the value of certain foreign silver coins, was passed in Committee— Then Bills to continue the Commissions on French and Neapolitan claims— The General Appropriation Bill followed, on an Amendment proposed by Philemon Dickerson of New-Jersey to the amendment proposed by Dudley Selden— After a discussion of two hours, both the Amendments were rejected— Samuel A. Foot of Connecticut moved to strike out the item of Salaries for Ministers to Great Britain and Russia, and to reduce the Appropriations 18000 dollars. He supported it by a short Speech, assigning his reasons. I sustained the motion upon entirely different grounds— Warren R. Davis of South-Carolina had yet other reasons which he gave but I could hear only part of what he said— What I did hear, and what he said with great feeling was this—turning towards me he said well do I remember the enthusiastic zeal with which we reproached the administration of that Gentleman, and the ardour and vehemence with which we laboured to bring in another— For the share that I had in those transactions, and it was not a small one, I hope God will forgive me, for I never shall forgive myself.— These were his identical words— Archer, Chairman of the Committee of foreign Relations, Polk, Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means, and especially Wayne of the same Committee defended with great
earnestness of the appropriation— I rose to reply but it was past 5.—the Committee rose, and the House adjourned— I find myself deeply and unexpected involved again in this debate; and greatly to my mortification.

Day.— Absorbed in regular attendance upon the House of Representatives— In the Morning I read a little, and in the Evening write a little—and sometimes spend it at a party of whist, with my family— The approach of Summer makes it irksome to write by evening Lamplight.
